‚ÄúEvery student at UConn should have a chance::: and worrying about food should not be something that a student is stressed out about."

UConn student organizers have created Husky Market::: a program that provides grocery store gift cards to students experiencing food insecurity ‚Äì the lack of consistent and reliable access to the financial resources needed to lead a healthy::: nutritious lifestyle. Established in 2019 to purchase groceries for students in need::: Husky Market pivoted during the COVID-19 pandemic to provide gift cards ‚Äì a contactless way to help that's sensitive to dietary restrictions and completely confidential. https://today.uconn.edu/2021/11/students-help-students-in-fight-against-food-insecurity/

TODAY.UCONN.EDU
Students Help Students In Fight Against Food Insecurity - UConn Today

column5: The words "malnutrition" and in some cases "starvation" are better terms than "food insecurity". No one should go hungry in a country as wealthy as ours. I read that Jeff Bezos has enough money to give every Amazon employee $110k. I guess he has "wealth security".
column6: This is great! I remember the "god ol' days" when we weren't fed on the weekends and some of us didn't really have the means to go out to eat......
column7: I‚Äôm impressed by what the students are doing. I had another daughter at a private university and while they discussed the topic::: they never took any useful action.

column1:
Doug Glanville was the first Black Ivy League graduate to play Major League Baseball::: spending nine years as an outfielder with the Cubs::: Phillies::: and Rangers. Now::: he teaches a popular class in the Neag School of Education called "Sport in Society."

The course's origin traces back to Glanville's personal experiences with racism and injustice after retiring from baseball in 2005. While working for ESPN as a play-by-play announcer::: he began to consider the intersection of sports and social justice.

‚ÄúWhen you feel racism::: you want it to change::: and you want that to happen now. I get that. But you have to embrace the slow work. It‚Äôs not sexy::: but it‚Äôs what actually lets you make change that sustains itself. The long game is what sticks.‚Äù Learn more about how Glanville plays "The Long Game" in the Fall '21 edition of #UConnMag. https://fal.cn/3jkdZ

MAGAZINE.UCONN.EDU
The Long Game

Where‚Äôs the fact check on this?
COVID-19 is NOT an airborne Illness. It‚Äôs primary mode of transmission is droplet which is why we have social distancing procedures. Please stop spreading misinformation.
Your caption could easily have been correct if you had simply changed the wording and eliminated false claims of COVID-19 being an airborne illness. And for everyone who wants to correct me and say I‚Äôm wrong::: please go to the WHO website where it states: ‚ÄúAccording to current evidence::: COVID-19 virus is primarily transmitted between people through respiratory droplets and contact routes.2-7 In an analysis of 75:::465 COVID-19 cases in China::: airborne transmission was not reported.7‚Äù and ONLY states that ‚ÄúIn the context of COVID-19::: airborne transmission may be possible in specific circumstances and settings in which procedures or support treatments that generate aerosols are performed; i.e.::: endotracheal intubation‚Ä¶‚Äù which is only a daily risk to healthcare workers performing these procedures on COVID-19 positive patients. Not to mention that this article SPECIFICALLY STATES that the masks being developed are being coated with a ‚Äúspray-coat superhydrophobi
c::: a highly fluorinated graphene oxide::: onto the outer surface of N95 respirators to develop a superhydrophobi
c N95 mask‚Äù. For those that don‚Äôt understand this jargon::: the term ‚Äòhydrophobic‚Äô means it does not let water in which ‚Äòdroplets‚Äô originate from respiratory sections aka. water based.

You are taking away from the wonderful work being done by the UCONN staff and others by spreading misinformation in your caption of the article. So please::: check your captions for accuracy before you post for the general public to read.

column3: Central Connecticut State University is creating a BA in General Studies like UCONN. They are proposing to require 15 credits above 300 level classes. I only have 6 credits above 300 level. UCONN requires 30 credits above 200 level to graduate. I have 25 credits above 200 level. If CCSU requires only 25 credits above 200 level then I can graduate with a BA in General Studies with a minor in Physics. Uconn would not accept CLEP so I could not transfer to UCONN as I have 33 credits of CLEP. I have had 128 credits for almost 20 years. I want to graduate with credits earned.

column5: One April Sunday in the late '60s after a break::: I left Maine to catch the bus in Boston to Storrs. A blizzard began along the way::: and by the time we reached Boston::: the Mass Pike was closed and the buses were cancelled except for the Arrow (?) driver who lived near Storrs. So::: through the snowstorm on back roads::: we slowly made our way to campus. Near midnight::: he made one stop at UConn to let us all off the bus. In loafers and a spring coat::: I trudged clear across campus to South Campus dragging my suitcase full of spring clothing.

column3:
This is a very critical topic. As a former UConn employee::: I wrote and developed educational materials about food and nutrition. I began in 1970::: a newly-minted English major. Long story short...communi
cating science isn't that different from basic journalism strategy...know
your audience::: learn what interests or motivates them::: use everyday language::: avoid using the passive voice::: tell stories. If you must use scientific or technical terms::: explain what they mean. But first::: in order to speak or write clearly::: you need to think clearly. I could go on::: but maybe another time!?!

column3: And if this is a slap in the face: President-Elect Joe Biden has nominated Tom Vilsack as Agriculture Secretary.  For anyone who is familiar with our Millions Against Monsanto campaign or who participated in March Against Monsanto during the Obama-Biden years::: you know why this is bad news.  For everyone else::: this is the first installment in our series of articles that will recount this history to explain why we opposed Vilsack‚Äôs nomination in 2009 and why we still do in 2021.  Tom Vilsack was ‚ÄúMr. Monsanto‚Äù even before he started at the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) in 2009. As Iowa‚Äôs governor (1999‚Äì2007)::: he had been named Governor of the Year by the Biotechnology Industry Organization. Today::: he continues to serve agribusiness as the head of the US Dairy Export Council::: which is deeply invested in perpetuating the system of CAFOs (concentrated animal feeding operations)::: the use of pesticide-drenc hed genetically modified feed::: and the practice of keeping prices paid to farmers below the cost of production to drive the consolidation of ever-larger factory farms.  As USDA Secretary from 2009-2017::: Vilsack approved more new genetically modified organisms (GMOs) than any Secretary before him or since. His GMOs include:  ‚Ä¢Monsanto‚Äôs Roundup Ready sugar beets. A judge ruled that innevitable contamination would cause the ‚Äúpotential elimination of farmer‚Äôs choice to grow non-genetically engineered crops::: or a consumer‚Äôs choice to eat non-genetically engineered food.‚Äù  ‚Ä¢Monsanto‚Äôs Roundup Ready sugar beets. A judge ruled that innevitable contamination would cause the ‚Äúpotential elimination of farmer‚Äôs choice to grow non-genetically engineered crops::: or a consumer‚Äôs choice to eat non-genetically engineered food.‚Äù  ‚Ä¢Monsanto‚Äôs Roundup Ready alfalfa::: the first genetically modified perennial crop. By the end of the Obama administration::: it had gone wild::: costing American alfalfa growers and exporters millions of dollars in lost revenue.  ‚Ä¢Monsanto‚Äôs DroughtGard corn::: which claimed a 4 percent yield advantage in field tests against conventional corn. The GMO corn was eclipsed by conventional corn grown after cover crops::: which demonstrated an 11 percent advantage-\-\duri ng the 2012 drought.  ‚Ä¢Monsanto‚Äôs dicamba-toleran t Xtend soy and cotton. Off-target drift of the volatile herbicide these crops are engineered to resist has destroyed millions of acres of non-resistant soy::: as well as nurseries::: vineyards::: vegetables::: trees::: native plants and ornamentals::: since Vilsack approved the new GMOs in 2015 and Obama-Biden‚Äôs Environmental Protection Agency cleared new versions of the weed killer in 2016. It‚Äôs been a nightmare for farmers and state pesticide regulators fielding complaints of crop destruction. Arkansas put a ban on using dicamba after May 25 and Illinois restricted dicamba use to June 30-July 15::: but that hasn‚Äôt stopped the damage in those states or across the country.  ‚Ä¢Scotts Miracle-Gro Roundup Ready lawn grass. Vilsack told the company it didn‚Äôt need federal approval or permits to conduct field trials or sell the seed commercially::: even though a different type of genetically engineered grass had already escaped from company test plots.  ‚Ä¢Syngenta's Agrisure corn. Vilsack stood idly by as this seed that contained genetically engineered traits-\-\that were illegal in China-\-\was sold to U.S. farmers. The corn crop was rejected::: costing farmers::: including those who didn't grow the new GMO::: at least $1.51 billion. Seven years later::: Syngenta (now owned by ChemChina) will soon be mailing settlement checks to impacted farmers.  ‚Ä¢Syngenta‚Äôs ethanol-only corn::: containing an engineered enzyme that makes the corn unsuitable for processing and consumption. Vilsack‚Äôs approval was over the opposition of the Corn Refiners Association::: the National Grain and Feed Association::: the North American Millers‚Äô Association::: the Pet Food Institute and the Snack Food Institute.  ‚Ä¢Dow (now Corteva)‚Äôs 2:::4-D-tolerant Enlist corn::: cotton and soy. A known endocrine disruptor and possible human carcinogen::: 2:::4-D is linked to cancer::: thyroid disorders::: decreased fertility and birth defects. Vilsack‚Äôs USDA projected that the new GMOs would mean the amount of 2:::4-D sprayed would grow between 200 and 600 percent by 2020. This was slowed by the wait for Chinese approvals of imports::: which were completed in 2019::: but the agricultural use of 2:::4-D has already seen a bump from 30 million pounds in 2005 to 44.4 million pounds in 2016.  ‚Ä¢J.R. Simplot Company‚Äôs Innate potatoes. Four years after Vilsack approved this RNA interference (RNAi) GMO::: Caius Rommens::: the former Monsanto scientist who invented it::: exposed the dangers of his work::: including the accumulation of at least two toxins that are absent in normal potatoes.  ‚Ä¢Okanagan Specialty Fruits‚Äô Arctic Apple. This apple that is bright green when juiced::: and doesn‚Äôt turn brown when it is bruised or starts to go bad::: was the first USDA approved GMO created with RNA interference. Granted::: it was FDA::: not USDA::: that should have investigated evidence that the double stranded RNA survives digestion and enters the bloodstream and tissues of the body::: where it can influence the functioning of the eater's cells. But::: Vilsack should have examined the plant pest risks: The chemical compound that is shut off in order to prevent the apple from browning is the same that protects it from insects::: injury and disease.  ‚Ä¢Cloned animals. When Vilsack was asked in 2010 if cloned cows or their offspring had made it into the North American food supply::: he claimed he didn‚Äôt know. Needless to say::: this aroused alarm. Europe moved for an embargo on imports of cloned animals and their produce and offspring. As did the National Organic Standards Board::: but Vilsack never issued regulations to make that official and he left the door open to the progeny of animals derived using cloning technology being allowed in USDA Organic. Since clones are most likely to be used as breeding stock::: especially dairy bulls::: it is very likely that the offspring of cloned animals are being used to produce organic milk and other food.  ‚Ä¢Synbio dairy substitutes. Vilsack allowed companies like Perfect Day to begin using genetically-alt ered yeast cultures to manufacture synthetic dairy substitutes‚Äïwit h no regulations to protect consumer health or the interests of family dairy farmers.  ‚Ä¢Lab-made meat. Vilsack let companies like Memphis Meat begin engineering cell-cultured meat under his watch without invoking the USDA‚Äôs regulatory authority to inspect or label it. No surprise that a former USDA staffer of his ended up lobbying for the company.  And::: for all that::: we have Tom ‚ÄúMr. Monsanto‚Äù Vilsack to thank!  If that‚Äôs not okay with you::: call your U.S. Senators and ask them to Vote No on Vilsack!

column1: #UConnMag | What‚Äôs keeping us out of self-driving cars? Hint: The answer has nothing to do with technology.  TODAY.UCONN.EDU UConn Magazine: In the Driver's Seat - UConn Today
column3: Humans are insanely good at image identification. Both software AND hardware aren‚Äôt up to the task yet .  I would say once life like images can be rendered real-time then they can be analyzed real-time.  Basically I‚Äôd say the appearance of video games correlates well with what we are capable of.
column4: Except it does have to do with technology. There's been many instances of semi-autonomous vehicles malfunctioning (not braking) and killing either the driver or a pedestrian. Additionally::: you face the practical problems of weather (frost obscuring sensors already is an issue on vehicles with automatic braking)::: how will it handle driving in different types of snow::: not getting stuck::: etc. There are so many variables to the driving conditions and each particular vehicle & drivetrain::: and now becomes even more complex with the different types of sensors and cameras a manufacturer may use. Beyond that::: how well can the system determine if an object in the road is a plastic bag::: a squirrel::: or a hazard that actually warrants slamming on the brakes? Let's not get into rural roads::: that's an entirely different animal.
column5: I think most people like the freedom of driving their own vehicles. The car driving itself just takes away more freedom. But the government needs to get out of the way too and let people decide for themselves if they want to purchase this technology.

column3: U.S. Air Force veteran. CLAS '05. Go Huskies!  I went to UConn after my tour. I remember living on base and coming home after a long day on the flight line. I was still in uniform going through the mail and saw the letter from UConn. I'll never forget the joy of reading that acceptance letter.
column4: Thank you for broadcasting this event today. I hope UConn always provides this Veteran's Day event virtually for those of us who can't make it to the Great Lawn area every 11/11. Thank you Dr. Bradford for an excellent speech. I watched the event live and then later in the evening on FB.
column5: Fwiw::: all of us were UConn Army ROTC (the Hangar) products Tim Murkett::: Ralph Hedenberg::: Daniel Murphy::: Vincent O'Neill to name a few. There are a bunch of us who left UConn to a military career::: it might be vgood press for UConn to consider writing a story angle on our grads in the future alum magazines. UConn has multiple Generals and Colonels from the CT National Guard from our year groups which is extremely unusual for an ROTC program - 3 of us were on active duty in California together::: also unusual considering the number of bases and how few of us graduated. The current 2 star CT National Guard general Fran Evon was our classmate. Another classmate ran RI's national guard. One of our classmates also played football for UConn::: Nate Cotton. One UConn classmate competed in the elite Best Ranger competition. I'm sure there are other stories here. You've got a great untold story other universities would want. Plus with all these new Vets needing to spend their new GI bill::: why not showcase your graduates? Syracuse right now does a really exceptional job here (and it stings for me to say that.). Villanova also is punching above their weight here as is Rutgers.

column1: What‚Äôs a nation to do with expired monuments? Two UConn professors weigh in on the topic from an education perspective.  TODAY.UCONN.EDU Op-Ed: Monuments 'Expire' - But Offensive Monuments Can Become Powerful History Lessons - UConn Today
column3: Ridiculous to say the least. Your true colors are showing UConn. You better start teaching rather than imposing your opinions on everyone.
column4: I find it fascinating that we can come away from this piece with such different opinions. There are those that will read this and understand that it's offering creative ways to repurpose old statues whose meanings have changed. And those that decry and disparage this professor's opinion as leftist propaganda undoubtedly have their own sensibilities that they adhere to. But let's remember that the purpose of a university experience is to get a variety of view points. Critical thinking begins with hearing opinions that differ from yours and then exploring why you might lean one way or the other. This is how learning works::: people.
column5: There is no such thing as an expired monument.

column17: While I appreciate cultural sensitivities I question where to draw the line? Will the books in the Babbage library be edited/removed to reflect current views? Most ‚Äúclassic‚Äù and prized literature has antiquated views with oppressive subject matter. Will the Dairy bar close because the livestock program has a byproduct of pollution from the animals? Will the State Oak trees be removed because they represent Connecticut‚Äôs rich::: lengthy and not always sensitive history? Will the Professors be fired due to non confirmation of current views? Or::: can we appreciate that history is rarely reflective of current views but there is a takeaway for future generations to learn from and improve. History does not expire it is a roadmap to the future. If your map does not show the hazards::: how do you know what to avoid? There is no ‚Äúbest‚Äù answer as someone will always have a differing view. The fact that public opinion is enacted is the privilege of our free country::: but this country did not become free without major sacrifices and conflict.

Memorializing traitors isnt"history." Its an attempt to change history so that few people can feel better about the whole racists traitor thing
column20: I apologize Prof Woodward; but 9/11 monuments will never expire. The sacrifice made by 3000 people on that day will never expire. America experience the very worst of humanity on that day::: but in the days that followed; we were the very best of America. Those monuments stand for all of those who rushed towards those scenes::: never to return home. To the people jumping to their deaths so they wouldn't burn alive; while holding hands with others. They stand for those brave passengers who overtook an aircraft and downed it in a field to save thousands of others they never knew.  And they also stand for the resilient America that showed its true colors in the days and weeks that followed. Political party lines erased::: the hour long lines to give blood::: American flags hung on every car::: on every bumper sticker::: on every house and every business. Volunteers showing up at the pile in NYC to help dig out survivors. The ferry operators taking thousands of people across the Hudson so they could return home. Those monuments have nothing to do with "homeland security" in the aftermath of 9/11 and everything to do with the sacrifices made because of twisted evil on that day and the beautiful soul America showed that day
column21: Your statement about the 9/11 monuments in this article is completely shocking- and completely incorrect.  Perhaps you don‚Äôt hail from the states that took the most grievous attacks‚Äî‚Äî- if you are proposing that the country‚Äôs awareness of the cost of homeland security has caused any American‚Äôs support of ANY 9/11 monument to wane...  I suggest you do a better job with the history and significance of your article.  A better job educating with the truth- not ignorance.  Those monuments you see represent not only the fact that actual real humans died FOR their country by taking down an airliner with full knowledge of the cost of both choices they faced - going to their own deaths - unsolicited but beyond BRAVE and fearless - it that others ran toward the attacks to save their fellow HUMAN beings....  plus the fact that these monuments represent unity AND resilience and pride in the values the nation offers ...  These monuments to and for 9/11 have not become expired..... don‚Äôt promote the notion - you become part of that problem if you actually expect any of us to believe your statement. Those who were not born or lived it- they can learn a lot by encountering these monuments.  You have only to look to events like the bombing at the Boston marathon to realize that NO -the American public does not think our intent with any of these 9/11 monuments has begun or ever needs to wane.....  There is no price that could explain the cost of misjudging American support for remembering ALL that came before and all that followed.  I think you need to completely rethink ever discussing 9/11 monuments with confederate leader statues::: and other monuments - because there is no comparison.  Completely different discussions.
column22: How about putting them back where they once stood you liberal pieces of shit. They were paid for and erected for a reason by the people of that community. I don't give a rats ass if you agree with them or not. More Americans appreciate them then not.
